text: Joseph Glickauf Jr. (January 15, 1912 – July 9, 2005), was an American-born engineer, inventor and corporate executive known as one of the first advocates of the use of computers in business and industry and the “father” of the computer consulting industry.Manya A. Brachear "Joseph Glickauf Jr.", The Chicago Tribune, Chicago, July 28, 2005. Retrieved on 10 November 2014. Joseph Glickauf was hired by Arthur Andersen Co. immediately after serving in the US Navy and was tasked with initiating the use of the freshly invented computer for his employer. Glickauf became familiar with the capabilities of the UNIVAC and immediately saw the far-reaching implications of computers for business. To demonstrate the computer to Arthur Andersen’s employees he built the Arthur Andersen Demonstration Computer known as “Glickiac”. The company management was quick to see the potential and made resources available for future development. In 1953 General Electric Appliance Park hired Arthur Andersen to automate GE’s payroll. Glickauf lead the effort and recommended GE the installation of a UNIVAC I computer and printer. The project was initially a failure but it started what is now known as the “computer consulting”. ==References== Category:Computer scientists Category:History of computing Category:1912 births Category:2005 deaths
